title-group.article-title: A Long Non-coding RNA DGCR5 May Contribute to Regulating Expression of Schizophrenia-Related Genes

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Medical Genetics, School of Life Science, Central South University, Changsha, Hunan, China.
2Institute for Genomics and Systems Biology, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA.
3University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, Colorado Center for Personalized Medicine, Aurora, CO 80045, USA.

5Departments of Pharmacology and Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Institute for Personalized Medicine, Penn State College of Medicine, Hershey, PA 17033, USA.

fn.p: Author contributions: A.T., D.F., H.E., L.J. and K.P.W. contributed to RNA extraction and RNA-sequencing. C.J., K.W., R.D. and Y.X. performed the WGCNA and key driver analysis. K.G., M.L., N.S., and Y.I.K. helped to revise the manuscript. C.C. and C.L. supervised the overall study design, guided the procedures and analyses, as well as manuscript preparation. Q.M. initiated the study and did the cell culture and qPCR experiments, led the manuscript writing. T.B. performed the differential gene expression analysis.
Competing interests: K.P.W is President and a shareholder in Tempus Labs, Inc.

abstract.p: A number of studies indicate that rare copy number variations (CNVs) contribute to the risk of schizophrenia (SCZ). Most of these studies have focused on protein-coding genes residing in the CNVs. Here, we investigated long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) within ten SCZ risk-associated CNV deletion regions (CNV-lncRNAs) and examined their potential contribution to SCZ risk. We used RNA-Seq transcriptomics data derived from postmortem brain tissue from control individuals without psychiatric disease as part of the PsychENCODE BrainGVEX and Developmental Capstone projects. We carried out weighted gene coexpression network analysis (WGCNA) to identify protein-coding genes coexpressed with CNV-lncRNAs in the human brain. We identified one neuronal function-related coexpression module shared by both data sets. This module contained a lncRNA within the 22q11.2 CNV region called DGCR5, which was identified as a hub gene. Protein-coding genes associated with SCZ GWAS signals, de novo mutations or differential expression were also contained in this neuronal module. Using DGCR5 knockdown and overexpression experiments in human neural progenitor cells derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells, we identified a potential role for DGCR5 in regulating certain SCZ-related genes.

abstract.title: One Sentence Summary:
abstract.p: The long non-coding RNA DGCR5 in the 22q11.2 deletion may regulate expression of certain protein-coding genes that have been associated with schizophrenia.

abstract.title: Accessible Summary:
abstract.p: Copy number variations (CNVs) have strong effects on risk of schizophrenia. However, the potential contribution of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) within CNV regions to SCZ risk is not clear. Through a genome-wide search, we identified that a lncRNA, DGCR5, inside 22q11.2 deletion regulates expression of many protein-coding genes related to schizophrenia GWAS signals, de novo mutation or differential expression. DGCR5 was found to be down-regulated in schizophrenia brains. Thus, DGCR5 may contribute to risk of schizophrenia through regulating expression of protein-coding genes implicated in schizophrenia.
